Storage.name: S3 Standard
features: Object storage with virtually unlimited scalability, accessed via API
Offers 99.999999999% (11 nines) of durability
Default storage class; designed for frequently accessed data
Offers high durability, availability, and performance
Use case: Websites, content distribution, and mobile/gaming applications
Provides low latency and high throughput

Storage.name: S3 Standard-IA
features: Object storage with virtually unlimited scalability, accessed via API
Offers 99.999999999% (11 nines) of durability
For data that is accessed less frequently, but requires rapid access when needed
Lower storage price but has a per-GB retrieval fee
Use case: Long-term storage, backups, disaster recovery files
Data is replicated across multiple Availability Zones

Storage.name: S3 One Zone-IA
features: Object storage with virtually unlimited scalability, accessed via API
Offers 99.999999999% (11 nines) of durability
Stores data in a single Availability Zone, making it less resilient
Cheaper than Standard-IA, but data is lost if the AZ fails
Use case: Storing secondary backup copies or easily recreatable data

Storage.name: S3 Glacier (Flexible & Instant)
features: Object storage with virtually unlimited scalability, accessed via API
Offers 99.999999999% (11 nines) of durability
Low-cost storage designed for data archiving and long-term backup
Instant Retrieval: Millisecond access for archives accessed quarterly
Flexible Retrieval: Configurable retrieval times from minutes to hours
Use case: Archiving data that needs occasional retrieval

Storage.name: EBS - General Purpose SSD (gp2/gp3)
features: Block storage, like a virtual hard drive for a single EC2 instance
Optimized for low-latency, consistent access within one AZ
Default SSD volume type; balances price and performance
Performance is based on IOPS and is 'burstable'
Ideal for a wide variety of workloads like boot volumes and web servers

Storage.name: EBS - Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1/io2)
features: Block storage, like a virtual hard drive for a single EC2 instance
Optimized for low-latency, consistent access within one AZ
Highest-performance SSD volume type
Delivers sustained, guaranteed IOPS performance
Ideal for large production relational or NoSQL databases

Storage.name: EBS - Throughput Optimized HDD (st1)
features: Block storage, like a virtual hard drive for a single EC2 instance
Optimized for low-latency, consistent access within one AZ
Low-cost magnetic (HDD) storage, optimized for Throughput (MiB/s)
Use for frequently accessed, large, sequential workloads
Ideal for big data, data warehousing, and log processing

Storage.name: EBS - Cold HDD (sc1)
features: Block storage, like a virtual hard drive for a single EC2 instance
Optimized for low-latency, consistent access within one AZ
Lowest-cost EBS volume type, optimized for Throughput (MiB/s)
Use when lowest storage cost is the primary factor for infrequently accessed data
Ideal for file servers or data that is rarely touched

Storage.name: EFS Standard Storage
features: File storage (NAS) that can be mounted to many EC2 instances simultaneously
Accessible across multiple Availability Zones within a Region
Default storage class for EFS, for frequently accessed files
Use Lifecycle Management to automatically transition files to IA

Storage.name: EFS Infrequent Access (IA) Storage
features: File storage (NAS) that can be mounted to many EC2 instances simultaneously
Accessible across multiple Availability Zones within a Region
Lower-cost storage class for files accessed less often
Optimizes cost for file systems with a mix of active and inactive data

Storage.name: EFS General Purpose Performance Mode
features: File storage (NAS) that can be mounted to many EC2 instances simultaneously
Accessible across multiple Availability Zones within a Region
Default performance mode, ideal for most applications
Optimized for latency-sensitive use cases like web serving and CMS

Storage.name: EFS Max I/O Performance Mode
features: File storage (NAS) that can be mounted to many EC2 instances simultaneously
Accessible across multiple Availability Zones within a Region
For highly parallel, large-scale workloads
Scales to higher levels of aggregate throughput and IOPS
Use for big data analytics and media processing

Storage.name: EFS Bursting Throughput Mode
features: File storage (NAS) that can be mounted to many EC2 instances simultaneously
Accessible across multiple Availability Zones within a Region
Default throughput mode, scales with file system size
Provides a baseline throughput and can burst to higher speeds
Ideal for spiky workloads with periods of high activity

Storage.name: EFS Provisioned Throughput Mode
features: File storage (NAS) that can be mounted to many EC2 instances simultaneously
Accessible across multiple Availability Zones within a Region
Set a specific, consistent level of throughput for your file system
Use when your application needs higher throughput than Bursting mode provides

Compute.name: EC2 Auto Scaling Group
features: Automatically adjusts the number of EC2 instances based on demand.
Maintains application availability and ensures desired capacity.
Can scale based on metrics (e.g., CPU utilization), a schedule, or predictively.
Works with Elastic Load Balancing to distribute traffic to a healthy fleet of instances.
A core component for creating elastic and fault-tolerant architectures.
Exam Keywords: 'elasticity', 'scalability', 'high availability', 'handle load'.

Compute.name: Cluster Placement Group
features: Packs instances close together inside a single Availability Zone.
Provides the lowest inter-instance latency.
Ideal for tightly-coupled High-Performance Computing (HPC) applications.
Increases risk of simultaneous failure if the underlying hardware fails.
Exam Keywords: 'low latency', 'HPC', 'tightly-coupled'.

Compute.name: Partition Placement Group
features: Spreads instances across logical partitions (separate hardware racks).
Reduces the likelihood of correlated hardware failures.
Each partition is isolated from the others.
Ideal for large distributed workloads like Hadoop, Cassandra, and Kafka.
Exam Keywords: 'distributed', 'replicated', 'fault tolerance', 'Hadoop/Cassandra'.

Compute.name: Spread Placement Group
features: Ensures each instance is on distinct underlying hardware.
Provides the maximum protection against simultaneous failures.
Used for a small number of critical instances that must be kept separate.
Ideal for applications like domain controllers or critical databases.
Exam Keywords: 'critical instances', 'maximum availability', 'separate hardware'.

Databases.name: Amazon RDS
features: A managed service for relational databases like MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, etc.
Automates time-consuming tasks like patching, backups, and recovery.
Optimized for Online Transaction Processing (OLTP).
Use case: Traditional applications, ERP, CRM, and e-commerce websites.
Exam Keyword: 'Relational database', 'SQL', 'OLTP'.

Databases.name: RDS - Multi-AZ
features: A feature of RDS for high availability and disaster recovery.
Creates a synchronous standby replica in a different Availability Zone.
Automatically fails over to the standby in case of an outage.
This is NOT for performance scaling; the standby cannot be read from.
Exam Keyword: 'High availability', 'fault tolerance', 'disaster recovery' for RDS.

Databases.name: RDS - Read Replicas
features: A feature of RDS for scaling read performance.
Creates asynchronous, read-only copies of your primary database.
Can be in the same region, cross-AZ, or cross-region.
Use case: Offloading read-heavy workloads like reporting or BI queries.
Exam Keyword: 'Scale reads', 'improve performance', 'reporting database'.

Databases.name: Amazon Aurora
features: A cloud-native relational database compatible with MySQL and PostgreSQL.
Offers higher performance, availability, and durability than standard RDS.
Storage is fault-tolerant and self-healing across 3 AZs by default.
Uses a shared storage volume that scales automatically.
Exam Keyword: 'High performance relational', 'cloud-native database'.

Databases.name: Aurora Serverless
features: An on-demand, auto-scaling version of Amazon Aurora.
Automatically starts up, shuts down, and scales compute capacity.
You pay on a per-second basis for the database capacity you use.
Ideal for infrequent, intermittent, or unpredictable workloads.
Exam Keyword: 'Unpredictable workload', 'intermittent traffic', 'serverless DB'.

Databases.name: Aurora Global Database
features: Allows a single Aurora database to span multiple AWS Regions.
Replicates data with low latency (<1 second) to secondary regions.
Enables fast, low-latency global reads and cross-region disaster recovery.
Exam Keyword: 'Global application', 'cross-region disaster recovery', 'low-latency global reads'.

Databases.name: Amazon DynamoDB
features: A fully managed, serverless NoSQL key-value and document database.
Delivers single-digit millisecond latency at any scale.
Scales horizontally by partitioning data across servers.
Use case: Mobile apps, gaming, session stores, and high-traffic web apps.
Exam Keyword: 'NoSQL', 'key-value', 'low-latency', 'serverless database', 'any scale'.

Databases.name: Amazon Redshift
features: A fully managed, petabyte-scale data warehouse.
Uses columnar storage and parallel processing for fast query performance.
Optimized for Online Analytical Processing (OLAP).
Use case: Business intelligence, analytics, and complex data queries.
Exam Keyword: 'Data warehouse', 'analytics', 'OLAP', 'columnar', 'BI queries'.

Databases.name: Amazon ElastiCache
features: A managed in-memory data store and cache service.
Supports Redis and Memcached engines.
Improves application performance by retrieving data from memory instead of disk.
Use case: Caching database queries, session stores, real-time leaderboards.
Exam Keyword: 'Cache', 'reduce database load', 'improve latency'.

Databases.name: DynamoDB Accelerator (DAX)
features: A fully managed, highly available, in-memory cache for DynamoDB.
Provides microsecond response times for read-heavy workloads.
It is transparent to the application; no code changes required.
Sits 'in front of' your DynamoDB table.
Exam Keyword: 'DynamoDB cache', 'microsecond latency', 'accelerate DynamoDB'.

Databases.name: Amazon QLDB
features: A fully managed ledger database.
Provides a transparent, immutable, and cryptographically verifiable transaction log.
Owned by a central trusted authority.
Use case: Systems of record, supply chain tracking, financial transactions.
Exam Keyword: 'Ledger', 'immutable', 'verifiable transaction log'.

Databases.name: Amazon Neptune
features: A fast, reliable, fully managed graph database service.
Built for querying highly connected datasets.
Use case: Social networking, recommendation engines, fraud detection.
Optimized for complex queries that explore relationships between data points.
Exam Keyword: 'Graph database', 'relationships', 'social network', 'recommendations'.

Networking.name: Application Load Balancer (ALB)
features: Operates at Layer 7 (Application Layer) for HTTP/HTTPS traffic.
Default choice for modern web applications and microservices.
Supports content-aware routing based on path or hostname.
Ideal for container-based architectures like ECS and EKS.
Can route traffic to serverless Lambda functions.
Supports WebSockets.

Networking.name: Network Load Balancer (NLB)
features: Operates at Layer 4 (Transport Layer) for TCP/UDP/TLS traffic.
Built for extreme performance and ultra-low latency.
Can be assigned a static or Elastic IP address.
Preserves the client's source IP address.
Ideal for gaming, IoT, and high-performance computing.
Use when you need to handle millions of requests per second.

Networking.name: Gateway Load Balancer (GWLB)
features: Operates at Layer 3 (Network) & Layer 4 (Transport).
Used to deploy, scale, and manage third-party virtual appliances.
Enables transparent inline traffic inspection for security.
Use case: Deploying firewalls, IDS/IPS, and deep packet inspection systems.
Centralizes security appliances for your VPCs.

Networking.name: Classic Load Balancer (CLB)
features: Operates at both Layer 4 (TCP) and Layer 7 (HTTP/HTTPS).
This is a legacy service and is not recommended for new applications.
Lacks the advanced routing features of an ALB.
Primarily for applications built within the EC2-Classic network.
NOTE: This is almost always the INCORRECT answer for new architectures.

Networking.name: AWS Direct Connect
features: Creates a private, dedicated, physical network connection from on-premises to AWS.
Bypasses the public internet, providing consistent, low-latency performance.
The ideal solution when high bandwidth and guaranteed performance are required.
You establish a connection to a Direct Connect location, not every AWS Region.
Exam Keywords: 'dedicated connection', 'high bandwidth', 'consistent latency'.

Networking.name: Direct Connect Gateway
features: A global routing hub that works with Direct Connect.
Allows a single Direct Connect connection to access VPCs in any AWS Region.
Simplifies multi-region connectivity from an on-premises network.
Traffic is routed privately over the AWS global backbone network.
Exam Keywords: 'connect to multiple regions', 'global VPC access', 'single Direct Connect'.

Networking.name: AWS VPN CloudHub
features: A feature of AWS Site-to-Site VPN that provides secure communication between sites.
Creates a hub-and-spoke model for connecting multiple on-premises networks.
All traffic routes through the central VPN hub in AWS.
Operates over the public internet, so performance is not guaranteed.
Exam Keywords: 'hub-and-spoke', 'site-to-site communication', 'branch offices'.

Networking.name: Elastic Network Adapter (ENA)
features: The standard, modern networking interface for most EC2 instances.
Provides high throughput (up to 100 Gbps) and reliable, low latency.
Enables 'Enhanced Networking' on supported instance types.
A great general-purpose network adapter for most workloads.
Exam Keywords: 'enhanced networking', 'high throughput'.

Networking.name: Elastic Fabric Adapter (EFA)
features: A specialized network interface for HPC and machine learning.
Provides an OS-bypass capability for extremely low and consistent latency.
Allows HPC applications to communicate directly with the network hardware.
Must be used with a Cluster Placement Group for best performance.
An AWS alternative to NIC Teaming
Exam Keywords: 'HPC', 'machine learning', 'OS-bypass', 'extremely low latency'.

Networking.name: Route 53 - Failover Routing
features: A routing policy used for active/passive disaster recovery.
You configure a primary resource and a secondary (standby) resource.
Route 53 monitors the health of the primary resource.
If the primary fails, traffic is automatically rerouted to the secondary.
Exam Keywords: 'active/passive', 'disaster recovery', 'primary/secondary'.

Networking.name: Route 53 - Weighted Routing
features: A routing policy that splits traffic between multiple resources based on percentages.
You assign a 'weight' to each record (e.g., 90% to A, 10% to B).
Used for active/active load balancing, canary testing, or blue/green deployments.
It is not used for a simple active/passive failover configuration.
Exam Keywords: 'split traffic', 'canary testing', 'blue/green', 'A/B testing'.

Networking.name: Route 53 - Alias Record
features: An AWS-specific record type that points to AWS resources (like ELB, CloudFront).
Can be used at the Zone Apex (e.g., example.com).
Queries are free and it automatically updates if the resource's IP changes.
The best practice for connecting domains to AWS resources.
Enables the 'Evaluate Target Health' feature.

Networking.name: Route 53 - CNAME Record
features: A standard DNS record that maps one domain name to another.
Cannot be used at the Zone Apex (e.g., example.com).
Less efficient than an Alias record as it requires an extra DNS lookup.
Should be avoided in favor of Alias records when pointing to AWS resources.
Does not support 'Evaluate Target Health'.

Networking.name: Route 53 - Evaluate Target Health
features: A setting for Alias records that integrates with Route 53 health checks.
When 'Yes', Route 53 considers the health of the backend resources (e.g., EC2 instances).
If the ELB is up but all its instances are down, Route 53 will see the target as unhealthy.
This is critical for enabling accurate and automatic failover.
Best practice is to set this to 'Yes' for failover configurations.

Security.name: Amazon GuardDuty
features: A managed threat detection service.
Continuously monitors for malicious activity and unauthorized behavior.
Analyzes CloudTrail logs, VPC Flow Logs, and DNS logs.
Use case: Detecting compromised EC2 instances or suspicious API calls.
Answers the question: 'Am I being attacked right now?'

Security.name: Amazon Inspector
features: An automated vulnerability management service.
Scans EC2 instances and container images for vulnerabilities.
Checks for unintended network exposure and software flaws (CVEs).
It is a proactive service to find weaknesses before they are exploited.
Answers the question: 'Where are my systems vulnerable?'

Security.name: Amazon Macie
features: A fully managed data security and data privacy service.
Uses machine learning to discover and protect sensitive data in Amazon S3.
Identifies data like Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and financial data.
Monitors S3 buckets for security risks like public access.
Answers the question: 'Where is my sensitive data in S3 and is it secure?'

Security.name: Amazon Cognito
features: Provides identity management for your applications.
Handles user sign-up, sign-in, and access control.
Supports social identity providers like Google, Facebook, and Apple.
Manages user pools (directories) and identity pools (for AWS credentials).
Answers the question: 'How do users sign in and get access to my app?'

Management & Governance.name: Amazon CloudWatch
features: The central monitoring and observability service for AWS.
Collects metrics, logs, and events from AWS resources and applications.
Can visualize data in dashboards and create alarms based on thresholds.
Use case: Monitoring EC2 CPU utilization or application error logs.
Answers the question: 'What is the health and performance of my resources?'

Management & Governance.name: AWS CloudTrail
features: Provides an audit log of all actions taken in your AWS account.
Records every API call, whether from the console, SDK, or CLI.
Used for governance, compliance, and operational auditing.
A critical data source for security analysis and troubleshooting.
Answers the question: 'Who did what, and when?'

Migration & Transfer.name: AWS DataSync
features: An online service for automated and accelerated data transfer.
Moves data between on-premises storage (NFS/SMB) and AWS storage (S3/EFS/FSx).
Handles scheduling, data integrity validation, and encryption.
It is a higher-level service that runs over a network connection (Internet/Direct Connect).
Exam Keywords: 'online migration', 'automated replication', 'NFS/SMB share'.

Migration & Transfer.name: AWS Snowcone
features: The smallest member of the AWS Snow Family of physical devices.
A small, rugged, and secure device with 8 TB of usable storage.
Used for offline data transfer or for edge computing use cases.
You fill it with data on-site and ship it to AWS.
Exam Keywords: 'small data job', 'edge location', 'portable device'.

Migration & Transfer.name: AWS Snowball Edge
features: A rugged, suitcase-sized device for petabyte-scale offline data transfer.
Comes in Storage Optimized (up to 80 TB) and Compute Optimized versions.
The primary tool for migrating large amounts of data when a network is not viable.
Can also be used for local storage and large-scale edge computing.
Exam Keywords: 'offline data transfer', 'petabyte-scale', 'slow network'.

Migration & Transfer.name: AWS Snowmobile
features: An exabyte-scale data transfer service.
It is a 45-foot long shipping container pulled by a semi-trailer truck.
Can transfer up to 100 PB of data per Snowmobile.
Used for migrating entire data centers or massive video libraries.
Exam Keywords: 'exabyte-scale', 'entire data center migration'.

Analytics.name: AWS Lake Formation
features: A service to build, secure, and manage a data lake in days.
Provides a central place to manage data access permissions.
Uses AWS Glue to crawl sources and populate a Data Catalog.
Enforces fine-grained access control (column, row, cell-level).
Exam Keywords: 'build data lake', 'centralized permissions', 'secure data'.

Analytics.name: AWS Glue Data Catalog
features: A central metadata repository for all your data assets.
A persistent technical metadata store, like a Hive Metastore.
Populated by AWS Glue Crawlers that scan data sources (like S3).
Provides the schema information needed by Athena, Redshift, and EMR.
Exam Keywords: 'metadata catalog', 'discover data', 'schema'.

Analytics.name: AWS Glue ETL
features: A fully managed, serverless ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) service.
Used to prepare and transform data for analytics.
Can automatically generate Python or Scala code for your ETL jobs.
You only pay for the resources used while your jobs are running.
Exam Keywords: 'serverless ETL', 'data preparation', 'transform data'.

Analytics.name: Amazon Athena
features: A serverless, interactive query service.
Allows you to run standard SQL queries directly on data in Amazon S3.
You do not need to load the data; you query it in-place.
Pay-per-query model, based on the amount of data scanned.
Exam Keywords: 'query S3 directly', 'serverless SQL', 'ad-hoc analysis'.

Analytics.name: Amazon EMR
features: A managed cluster platform for big data processing.
Simplifies running big data frameworks like Apache Hadoop and Apache Spark.
Use case: Large-scale ETL, log analysis, and machine learning.
You manage a cluster of EC2 instances.
Exam Keywords: 'big data processing', 'Hadoop/Spark cluster', 'log analysis'.

Analytics.name: Amazon Kinesis Data Streams
features: A service for ingesting and storing massive volumes of real-time data.
Data is stored in 'shards' for 24 hours by default (up to 365 days).
Producers send data to the stream; multiple consumers can process it.
Use case: Real-time collection of application logs, clickstreams, IoT data.
Exam Keywords: 'real-time streaming', 'ingest data', 'producers/consumers'.

Analytics.name: Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose
features: The easiest way to load streaming data into data stores.
Captures, transforms, and loads streaming data with no management.
Destinations include S3, Redshift, Elasticsearch, and Splunk.
It is near real-time, with a minimum buffer of 60 seconds.
Exam Keywords: 'load streaming data', 'S3/Redshift destination', 'near real-time'.

Analytics.name: Amazon Kinesis Data Analytics
features: A service to process and analyze streaming data in real time.
Uses standard SQL or Apache Flink to run queries on data streams.
Can read data directly from Kinesis Data Streams or Firehose.
Use case: Time-series analytics, real-time dashboards, and real-time alerts.
Exam Keywords: 'analyze streaming data', 'real-time SQL', 'time-series analytics'.

Analytics.name: Amazon QuickSight
features: A scalable, serverless, embeddable, machine learning-powered Business Intelligence (BI) service.
Used to create and publish interactive dashboards and visualizations.
Can connect to a wide variety of data sources like S3, Redshift, RDS, and Athena.
Features a pay-per-session pricing model, making it cost-effective.
Exam Keywords: 'BI', 'dashboards', 'visualizations', 'business analytics'.
